title: Homes in the U.K. Selling at Slowest Rate in Three Years
text:
Home sales in the U.K. reached their slowest pace in the third quarter in three years, according to a report Wednesday by Zoopla, a London-based real estate company.



Residential properties took an average of about 12 weeks to find a buyer, the longest amount of time since the third quarter of 2016, when homes were selling in about eight weeks, the report found. At the same time, sellers are accepting offers that are an average of 3.8%, or £9,800 (US$12,617) lower than the initial asking price.



Uncertainty over Brexit is an issue in many regions of the U.K., but it’s just one factor causing the slowdown.

“Removing the uncertainty caused by Brexit will do little to address levels of housing affordability, which is limiting market activity across southern England,” Richard Donnell, research and insight director at Zoopla, said in the report.



Still, “once the political outlook becomes clearer, we would expect a modest bounce-back in demand for a six- to 12-month period,” he added.



In London, homes are taking even longer to sell, spending an average of 14-and-a-half weeks on the market before finding a buyer. And homes in the capital are selling for an average of 5.7% below asking price, according to the report.

These figures differ between inner and outer London, the report stated. A home in inner London could take an average of 20 weeks to sell, at a 7.6% or £49,824 discount, while a home on the outer fringes of the city sells in an average of 12.2 weeks for about 4.7% less than the asking price.

Homes in the Midlands, in the center of the country, and the North of England, have fared better. About 75% of cities in these regions see homes sell in between 8.4 and 9.5 weeks, while only dropping asking prices 2% or 3%, the report found.



The market in Scotland is also strong. Homes in Glasgow and Edinburgh sell within an average of five to six weeks, the report found. Properties in those cities are also fetching an average of 6% to 7% above the asking price.
